QuestionJSON.Question: Haskell and their friends are basketball enthusiasts, they're also developing a new basketball video game. After months of testing, they've noticed the game begins to predict when the AI-controlled teams should commit fouls, but this prediction is greatly skewed. Teams with white-colored jersey avatars statistically commit fewer fouls than the teams with black-colored jersey avatars. Although this was unintentional, they recognize that the coding of their game may implicitly carry a bias. What approach should Haskell and their team do to address the issue?
QuestionJSON.Answer1: Haskell should leave it as it is - after all, it's just a game.
QuestionJSON.Answer2: Haskell should let the users figure out their own solution to this problem.
QuestionJSON.Answer3: Haskell should apologize to the community without making any code modifications.
QuestionJSON.Answer4: Haskell and their team should work to identify the section of their code that is attributing the color of the avatar's jersey to the chance of committing a foul, and correct it. The AI should consider only factors related to gameplay, e.g., aggression, defense ratings, etc.
QuestionJSON.Explanation: Bias, intentional or not, in a game design can reinforce stereotypes and unfair practices. Identifying and rectifying this bias will lead to a more equitable and fair game play. The AI's decision to commit a foul should be independent of the jersey's color.
